Kutze is a talented enough scientist to continue his work happily in his Warsaw lab, but as Largo points out, any scientific discoveries he made would amount to nothing but a million dollars for a Nobel Prize, while his efforts in SPECTRE would give him endless amounts more. In this way, a good man like Kutze is tempted to the side of the organization where his efforts-no matter how inherently bad they are-will be well rewarded and appreciated by the hierarchy in a far greater capacity than the scientific community could ever manage, which is a tantalizing temptation. There’s a slight implication that Kutze may have been “persuaded” against his will by SPECTRE to come along and help on the NATO operation, which would give credence to their overreaching power and explain why the scientist later turns against Largo and his crew when he can stomach their actions no longer.

Each of these factors contribute to the feeling of drama that unfolds during Thunderball. Because we are welcomed behind the veil of SPECTRE and see their plot form incrementally from behind sealed walls, their ransom of the world with the ultimate threat of nuclear destruction cuts all the deeper. Experiencing Blofeld’s Paris briefing with his agents makes us feel like the invasive ones, as if we shouldn’t be witnessing what we are. We stiffen helplessly as we see all the counter moves that are being made by SPECTRE to offset the British and American governments, and James Bond through proxy. Although we know deep in the back of our minds that 007 has to succeed in his mission, doubt is nonetheless seeded early on through the NATO plot.

Direction-

After sitting out Goldfinger when he felt he had nothing more to provide to the Bond brand, Terence Young signed on for the Thunderball project to tie off his work with the character with great finality. After Goldfinger had marveled the world and made Bond even more of an international icon, Young knew that the fourth time around the track his Bond had to be bigger than ever, with not even the sky being the limit of its scope.

What resulted was no doubt his most ambitious and logistically challenging Bond production by a landslide, and he almost died during his second Bond film, if that tells you something. Thunderball demanded that Young juggle, advise and shoot over one hundred extras and crew members in the Bahamas in and around heavily packed locations that offered little wiggle room with film equipment and gear that amounted to over twelve tons in weight. He was able to reign in the chaos and bring the film into port with psyche unbroken, however, in no small part thanks to one of the all-time greatest production teams in cinema.

It’s fitting that Thunderball marks Young’s third and final go at a Bond film, because the film represents a culmination of all his strengths as a director, as well as what made his Bond films special, with an added shot of ambition thrown in to credibly tell the story he was assembling. Young’s shooting style and chemistry with his actors is visible on his return, as is his tenacious ability to get shots nobody else could have managed even half as well.

As far as the story is concerned, Thunderball is the perfect offspring of Dr. No and From Russia with Love, retaining the mystery and detective-styled narrative of the former and a tense and dangerous SPECTRE conspiracy best seen in the latter. Thunderball under Young’s direction takes the best of Bond, adapts it to the new story and adds new twists into the mix to make things interesting. The SPECTRE plot is dire and mind-blowing in its consequence, and the amount of time we are underwater with or without Bond really sets this film apart as special and like no other. This is the water Bond film, fitting for the climate of the Bahamas which it is set around.

I would be erring if I didn’t also include a special recognition of the work of Ricou Browning, who, along with his cameraman Lamar Boren and engineer Jordan Klein, was able to direct the underwater sequences of Thunderball and bring them to glorious life. The second-unit of this movie really had their work cut out for them, but thanks to Browning and his team, who assembled, choreographed and shot the feverish action and built the many underwater machines used in each underwater sequence (like the gear that transports the two nukes with an original design by Ken Adam), we get to enjoy it all. It would be difficult to believe that Terence Young didn’t direct the underwater sequences, including the final battle, because the camera work and stunts are exquisitely produced and shot with an artistic eye. The divers we see cast as Navy frogmen and SPECTRE agents in the final battle are made up of a team of specialists Browning himself, a dedicated diver and stuntman, had brought to the Bahamas to shoot the sequence.

Thanks to the widescreen presentation of Thunderball, the underwater crew used the expanded frame to their advantage, filling the camera’s picture box with dozens of extras battling it out with knives and spear guns in awe-inspiring fashion. There’s an epic feeling these sequences carry, and the images we get are some of my favorites in the film. We cut from shots of tussling divers to those of sea creatures reacting to the chaos unfolding around them, juxtaposed with images of dead frogmen and SPECTRE agents sinking to the ocean floor with blood rushing out of their wounds. Everything we see feels alive and real, and never comes off like a staged film production. At times I think I’m watching a snuff film as the stuntmen realistically stab each other with knives, movements that are backed up by perfect sound design to convey the power of the killing blows as blood trails swarm out of their bodies.

I haven’t ever and likely will never see a film with better shot and choreographed underwater photography than Thunderball, or one that balances logistical challenges with the finesse it managed. There were so many stuntmen to manage and command during the filming of this sequence, and so many logistical challenges to juggle and balance when it came to film equipment and keeping continuity with the events being filmed, yet the filmmakers are able to make it look so easy, throwing in some stunning photography to boot as the bright orange frogmen pop amid the crisp blues of the deep. The result is the definition of movie magic, showing the amazing results you can achieve with a lot of work, manpower and creativity.

In another special mention, United States Air Force Lieutenant-Colonel Charles Russhon, who helped EON get the necessary authority to shoot in Turkey for From Russia with Love and fly over the real Fort Knox in America for Goldfinger, returned again for Thunderball. For his part, Russhon provided the second-unit with the experimental rocket fuel used to blow the Disco Volante to smithereens, and also secured EON’s access to the fulton surface-to-air recovery system from the United States Navy that appears at the very end of the movie to get Bond and Domino out of dodge. The latter was a true to life spy tool used in the profession to get agents out of dangerous locations, giving Thunderball even more of a grounded feeling despite its blockbuster essence.

All these factors are a testament as to why the Bond team of the 60s is unmatched in every way: they took immense challenges and found clever ways to get the job done with their amazing cast of associates and problem eliminators.

Opening Title Design-

Coming off of Robert Brownjohn’s stunning back-to-back opening title designs for From Russia with Love and Goldfinger, Maurice Binder returned for the first time since Dr. No to provide the introductory credits to Thunderball. Brownjohn’s titles were so impressive in their cleverness and style, so it’s only fitting that Binder’s own design arriving just after those two would be just as striking and unexpected. Looking through his vast catalogue of James Bond title designs that stretched into the late 80s, the one he delivered for Thunderball could be his crowning achievement for how it is able to truly stand on its own.

Whereas Brownjohn always preferred to work with the canvases of three-dimensional human bodies, Binder chose to use the almost 2D looking effect of swimming silhouettes to bring the opening titles of Thunderball to life. It was in this very design that the man introduced the use of nude female bodies as an ingredient in a credit sequence, an innovation that would remain throughout the entire life of the series, even to this day. If a title design for a new Bond film rolls around and there’s not at least one shot of a female silhouette in it, the criticisms you’ll hear in response are all down to the iconic tradition that was started with this movie.

Binder’s title design realizes its success by being both dynamic and gymnastic, all at once. The dynamism is derived from the very rich and vibrant use of blues, reds, greens and purples as the color of the background is shifted on a dime, and the gymnastic quality is captured through how the divers are photographed as they move through the frame. The images of women twisting and turning in the water are very straightforward and easily consumable, but they go a long way towards proving that simplicity can sometimes be best. Using just a tank full of water at Pinewood studios, Binder was able to create the entire sequence from the ground up with a small group of divers on hand. Instead of throwing everything at the wall to see what stuck, he mindfully chose not to muddle a simple concept with an over abundance of motifs or visual noise. Through restraint, these titles hit a sweet spot.

The real magic of the entire sequence is down to how Binder was able to create an almost 3D effect with silhouettes that come off as blackened bits of 2D moving art. While the divers begin by swimming from side to side, giving them a 2D impression, as the sequence goes on they break the convention and gravitate towards the camera itself, popping out as their dimensional selves. At specific moments in the titles we watch the female divers swim straight at the camera before rising up and out of frame, as if they were avoiding a collision. In other instances, the male divers create the same effect as they tear across the screen from the background, armed with spear guns and seemingly going for the kill as they chase after the women, giving the sequence more than an ounce of threat.

Like a cartoon jumping off of a comic book page, somewhere along the line the concept of 2D and 3D compromise and mesh as a surreal effect is created and the visuals are given a “pop” by design. I would love to watch this particular title sequence in theaters with 3D glasses for this very reason, to witness the bizarre effect of the divers swimming right for me.

The use of various divers, lush colored backgrounds and water effects to create bursts of water and rising bubbles come together to make the Thunderball titles like no other we have ever seen in the Bond series before or since. The underwater imagery is inseparable from the film itself and its own emphasis on showing characters fighting for survival as they dive below great depths, creating a design that unifies the movie as a whole. Tom Jones’ opening tune only adds more bravado and might to the proceedings as the notes ringing out further accentuate the cinematic and highly masculine images Binder has designed for us to take in.

Script-

I have stated my love for the script of Thunderball in the previous sections of my analyses in the categories of “plot plausibility” and “villain’s scheme,” so I will add my final thoughts here to further argue why I find this script so strong in particular.

Firstly, Thunderball does what so little films can seem to manage to do, even outside of Bond: it welcomes us into the villains’ homes, figuratively and literally. We get a window into SPECTRE, how the organization is run and what Bond is up against. We see firsthand how they are planning to meticulously get their nukes, and what steps they’ve taken to make sure their seizure of the weapons is successful. Some think it’s a weakness on the part of Thunderball to show us so much of SPECTRE’s plans and how they unfold, but I view it as quite special and thrilling. Part of the reason why From Russia with Love is so different and fascinating is because it too allows us inside the minds of the villains as we see how and why they are acting out their plans in the ways they are. We see the shadow of SPECTRE gradually swallow up Bond and cast him into doubt and danger, and that’s nothing short of thrilling.

It makes Thunderball special that we get to know Bond’s greatest enemies, that we get to see how their organization is run and how the SPECTRE briefing under Blofeld contrasts with the later 00 briefing under the command of M, two vastly different leaders with different causes and morals, both expecting the best of their agents. We see how Largo and his crew get the nukes and all the problem solving they perform to ensure their plans are a success. This makes it very difficult to nitpick the holes of Thunderball beyond some conveniences because the movie strives to show us how the villains are doing what they are doing step-for-step.

Secondly, in Thunderball Bond is back to being a man of action, a dynamic, not static character, unlike in the previous film. The Terence Young Bond returns, the half spy half detective super combo who meticulously bugs his hotel room to survey any enemy action against him, who uses his cleverness to eradicate his enemies, and who completes his mission by any means necessary, regardless of the increasing odds stacked against him. In Young’s films we get to see Bond subtly develop from a man who had no idea of SPECTRE’s existence in Dr. No and who became an ant-sized agent under the hell of the organization in From Russia with Love to a man who now knows his enemy well and is irreverently confident and devil may care in the face of Blofeld and his agents.

Bond smells SPECTRE all over the NATO plot, and when he meets the plan’s architect, Largo, he immediately mocks the man and lets him know he is aware of his organization’s scheme and his connection to it. Both men know who each other are as they meet at the card table, nobody else, and Bond rather cavalierly defeats Largo in a pompous way while still keeping it gentlemanly in a nice sequel to the Dr. No card game that debuted the character to the world. It’s clear that after having two missions where he was in over his head and blind to SPECTRE’s influence, Bond refuses to be duped a third time around, and that makes him more dangerous to the organization than ever before: the gloves are off and he’s playing no games.

The subtle black comedy of Thunderball’s script gives it even more character as a piece of writing because in it beautiful or harmless imagery is contrasted directly with images that are evil or dangerous by design. As if out of Stanley Kubrick’s Dr. Strangelove, the nuclear weapons Largo and his crew are seizing have a label painted on them that reads, “Handle like eggs.” This element always strikes me as both funny and frightening at the same time, as the label brings to mind the soft and harmless imagery of eggs in a carton while being overlaid on top of the delicate, volatile and serious weaponry of the nukes. Because of the visual metaphor forged between eggs and nukes here, I can feel the hair on my arms stand on end as I picture Largo and his team trying to cautiously remove and transport the missiles around the Bahamas, with me always anxious that they’re destined to go kaboom if any excitable movement is made on their part and the weaponry are triggered to their finite reaction. A nice touch.

As a greater theme, Thunderball is a story of concealment, where everything is being hidden between the characters, even when the truth is right under the nose. The beauty and grace of Fiona masks a deadly and resourceful tactician, just as Bond’s dapper suits deceive those around him and SPECTRE’s Paris headquarters is concealed inside a quaint social services building. Domino’s innocence and sweetness hide away the tragedy of her character and the pain she faces under the thumb of Largo, and the Vulcan plane Bond is so intent on tracking is purposely hidden from sight in camouflage net. Even the British and American governments are lying to the innocent citizens of the world. Both world powers know the consequences of their failure to retrieve the nukes, as well as the severe aftermath that would come following a nuclear attack on a major English or American city, but they can’t share the dreaded news with the world for fear of the catatonic panic it would cause and what the leak would drive SPECTRE to do in retaliation.

It’s in these moments that Thunderball’s razor sharp script puts an emphasis on race against time stakes. Back in Britain, M and his superiors are forced into agreeing to SPECTRE’s demands, ringing Big Ben the demanded 7 times to signal their arrangement. The government reports this ringing as a mechanical failure to the public, masses who are unaware in their ordinary lives of just how close the world is to reaching a possible breaking point. It is downright thrilling to know that while Bond is in the Bahamas trying every avenue of strategy to locate the nuclear missiles as the clock winds down-from causing an island-wide blackout to crashing Largo’s estate and manipulating his mistress-the people of Miami and/or Britain have no idea how close they are coming to being decimated. Even when the film concludes and Bond’s team stops the SPECTRE scheme from coming to fruition, the denizens of Florida and his native land back home don’t know him from Adam, even though he’s the only thing that came between them and utter vaporization. Thunderball also does a better job than most of the films at showing the real stakes that are set against Bond’s survival. Throughout the film Bond courts death itself often, by shark and by bullet, and finds himself stumbling into a crowded club with a bloodied wound to his leg at his most dire. Defenseless and preyed on, our hero must turn the tides in his favor and become a predator once again. As with every Young film, the script delivers us a Bond who can be shaken without being stirred, and who uses his brains and a little brawn to get himself out of some desperate circumstances. Because it’s not easy for him his victories are more triumphant, no matter how fleeting they will soon be rendered.

In light of the above elements, Thunderball goes a long way toward showing us what a thankless job Bond has when he can walk down the street staring people directly in the eyes who exchange no pleasant words with him, even though they wouldn’t be around if it weren’t for his expertise in spy craft. Bond goes all in for humanity with his every breath, but can never share his feats and gambles with anyone outside the agency on professional principle. His sacrifices must go on unnoticed and unrewarded, cast in shadow, never to see the light. Such is the life of a spy whose risks so often meet no rewards.

In conclusion, Thunderball’s script is a rich and exciting mix of theme, dialogue and character that packs a heavy punch. The immense tension created as Bond races to stop doomsday is a perfect culmination of what made Young’s Bond films so special and mind-bending in the first place with their emphasis on showing Bond overcome danger alongside fleshed out and dimensional allies and enemies.
